awd_titl_txt: GOALI: Diamond Coated Carbon Fiber Wire Sawing of Silicon Ingots
awd_abstract_narration:
Diamond coated wire sawing of silicon ingots into individual wafers accounts for 11 percent of solar cell production costs. This cost is primarily associated with generation of silicon powder which is a waste stream and requires energy intensive recycling strategies. Thinner wires can lead to minimal powder generation during wire sawing. However, thinner steel wires (smaller than 100 microns in diameter) break easily under the stress required for efficient cutting of silicon. This Grant Opportunity for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) award supports scientific investigations on the use of carbon fiber wires smaller than 100 microns in diameter in diamond coated wire sawing of silicon ingots into wafers. Research results from this project will lead to reduced wastage of silicon and, therefore, reduced dollar-per-watt of silicon based solar cells. 

The first research objective is to establish relationships between sawing conditions (such as wire velocity and normal force) and the chemical and structural changes of individual diamond particles coated on a carbon fiber wire. The changes observed in the diamond particles are softening (i.e., graphitization), cleavage, blunting, or complete removal from the carbon fiber wire. The approach to achieve this objective is to measure chemical and structural changes after sawing in diamond particles, carbon fiber wire, and generated silicon powder using micro-Raman spectroscopy. This technique can map chemical and structural changes in the diamond particles, carbon fiber wire and the silicon powder with micron scale spatial resolution. An industrial sawing machine, and single crystalline silicon ingots with a 15 cm x 15 cm square cross-section, will be used for sawing experiments. Wire velocities of up to 25 m/s and a normal force of up to 15 N will be used. The second research objective is to understand the effects of wear of diamond particles and carbon fiber on sawing rate. The approach to achieve this objective is to measure, in situ, wire bowing of the diamond coated carbon fiber wire as it performs sawing. This allows estimation of wire tension and frictional forces experienced by the wire inside the silicon kerf during sawing. As wear proceeds, wire bowing increases and so do frictional forces. Sawing rate will be measured as the vertical velocity of the silicon ingot as it presses down on the wire. Parameters such as carbon fiber wire diameter (from 60 µm to 100 µm) and diamond size (from 6 µm to 20 µm) will be varied.

por.por_cntn:
With this award, the use of Raman microspectroscopy has been widened to understand properties of materials currently used in silicon based solar cells.

Silicon based solar cells capture over 95% of the solar cell market. Their production process requires careful control over the quality, accuracy and placement of functional materials on a silicon substrate, which ultimately determines the efficiency and reliability of solar cells. Diagnosis of structure and properties of materials used in solar cells can be of great importance in establishing efficiency and lowering cost of manufacturing for a solar cell. To this end, the use of Raman microspectroscopy as a metrology tool provides several key advantages. First, Raman microspectroscopy is a non-destructive technique performed in ambient. Second, the technique can provide key information on a material such as crystallinity and chemistry and properties such as mechanical stress, in microscopically small volumes of materials. Thus, the use of Raman microspectroscopy on solar cells can lead to improved understanding of materials and structures and their interaction with the silicon substrate at the microscopic level, in turn shedding light on processes that are used for solar cell manufacturing.  

Through several publications, it has been shown that Raman microspectroscopy can successfully identify regions on the silicon substrate with remnants of saw marks - damaged regions which are left over from the silicon wafering process. Additionally, the conducting silver wires show signs of oxidation during their 'firing' process that can lead to lower electrical conductivity. Finally, in a first of its type, a particle embedded on the surface of silicon has been probed as a 3-dimensional map that shows this inclusion to be nanocrystalline silicon (see Figure).

The award led to the publication of five journal articles and two conference proceedings. One patent application has been filed resulting from partial support derived from this award. One doctoral student graduated with a PhD in materials science and engineering. Work from this award was presented at multiple international conferences and colloquia including the Photovoltaic Specialists Conference (PVSC) and the Florida Solar Energy Center. Two undergraduate, underrepresented minority students conducted summer research through the award's research experience for undergraduates supplemental funding. Two undergraduate seniors conducted their senior design thesis on this award.


Last Modified: 07/21/2023
Modified by: Parag Banerjee

Image
  • A 3-dimensional reconstruction of a nanocrystalline silicon inclusion (red) embedded inside a silicon solar cell (green). Raman microspectroscopy under the confocal mode was used to identify the nanocrystalline phase clearly differentiating it from a background of crystalline silicon
    Ganesan, J. P.; Iqbal, N.; Krsmanovic, M.; Torres-Davila, F.; Dickerson, A.; Davis, K. O.; Tetard, L.; Banerjee, P., Raman Microspectroscopy of a Multi-Crystalline Silicon Solar Cell. IEEE J. Photovoltaics 2022, 12 (1), 230-237.
    Copyright owner is an institution with an existing agreement allowing use by NSF
    Parag Banerjee
    Silicon microparticle inclusion embedded inside a silcon solar cell
